bibl.title: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter, May 22, 1917

div1.p: Carter discusses a possibly mis-diagnosed case of yellow fever.

Who is Guiteras' pathologist? It would not be a
bad thing to consult Whitmore or Welch as to his standing,
for if the nature of the “Country Fever” of Martinique,
Maracaibo and other parts of Venezuela, is to be investigated
the pathologist should be a man whose determination carries
weight, and I cannot help remembering Lobredo's paper at
the last Congress on the infectious origin of Beri Beri,
and his “infected race” that produced it.

If Darling is available as one of your previous
letters implied, he is not only competent, but known to be
competent, and his finding would be generally accepted.

On the other it would be an advantage, especially
if I cannot go, to have a man familiar with Dengue, and
Six Day Fever, as they occur in America. It is not at all
improbable that the Dengue of Asia, is not the same disease
as that known in America.
